title: Am I non-binary?
opening_message: "I've been feeling really uncomfortable with the idea of identifying as a woman lately, and I'm not sure why - maybe it's because it just doesn't feel right to me."

all: I never had a problem with being assigned female at birth.
My best friend coming out as trans opened my eyes to gender identity and non-binary terms.
When I shared my suspicions about being agender with my partner, he dismissed it and said "no, you're not".
Despite feeling uneasy, I put the idea away and continued presenting as female, but now feel uncomfortable using the word "woman".
Female pronouns still feel okay to me, which adds to my confusion.
I'm struggling to understand why the word "woman" doesn't feel like me.
I've been feeling a sense of discomfort with gender labels and expectations.
My experience is confusing even to myself - I don't know how to reconcile my comfort with female pronouns with my unease with the term "woman".
I'm seeking insight into what it means to be non-binary and how others have navigated their own experiences.
I'm hoping to find a sense of understanding and clarity about my gender identity.
used: I'm struggling to understand why the word "woman" doesn't feel like me.
My experience is confusing even to myself - I don't know how to reconcile my comfort with female pronouns with my unease with the term "woman".
When I shared my suspicions about being agender with my partner, he dismissed it and said "no, you're not".
I've been feeling a sense of discomfort with gender labels and expectations.
Female pronouns still feel okay to me, which adds to my confusion.
Despite feeling uneasy, I put the idea away and continued presenting as female, but now feel uncomfortable using the word "woman".
My best friend coming out as trans opened my eyes to gender identity and non-binary terms.
I'm hoping to find a sense of understanding and clarity about my gender identity.

turns.content: "I've been feeling really uncomfortable with the idea of identifying as a woman lately, and I'm not sure why - maybe it's because it just doesn't feel right to me."

"Ah, I totally get it. It can be tough when our identities or labels don't quite fit anymore. Can you tell me more about what specifically feels off about identifying as a woman? Is there something specific that's making you question it?"

"I guess what I mean is, when people say 'woman', my mind goes to all these traditional ideas about femininity and gender norms... it's just not who I am or want to be. It feels like a label that doesn't reflect the complexity of my identity."

"Ah-ha, I think I'm starting to understand where you're coming from! You're feeling like the term 'woman' is tied up in societal expectations and norms, rather than being a true representation of who you are. That can be really frustrating when we're trying to find a label that feels authentic. What do you think would be a more fitting label or description for your identity?"

"I think that's a really good point, and yeah, it can be frustrating when we're trying to find a label that feels true to ourselves. For me, it's like... I don't know if 'non-binary' is the perfect fit either, because on one hand, it acknowledges that gender isn't binary for me, but on the other hand, it's still tied up in these societal expectations and norms that feel limiting. And then there's this whole thing with pronouns - I'm comfortable being referred to as 'she', but at the same time, it feels like it's reinforcing this idea of womanhood that doesn't entirely resonate with me."

"I totally get what you're saying! You're feeling like 'non-binary' might not be the perfect fit either, because it still carries some of those societal expectations and norms. And I can see how pronouns can be a tricky thing - wanting to be referred to in a way that feels comfortable for you, but also not wanting to reinforce certain gendered ideas. Can you tell me more about what would feel like a more empowering or authentic way to refer to yourself?"

"Ah, yeah... I think what's hard for me is that when I tried to explore this feeling of being agender with someone close to me, they basically shut down any possibility of considering it. It felt like they were more concerned with preserving their own understanding of me rather than actually listening to my experience. That made me feel like my feelings and identity weren't valid or worthy of exploration."

"I'm so sorry you went through that. It sounds like it was a really invalidating experience, and I can imagine how hurtful it must have been. When someone close to us dismisses our experiences and feelings without truly listening, it can be incredibly isolating. How did that make you feel about your own identity and the exploration of your gender?"

"It's funny, I think for a while after that happened, I started to feel like my gender was somehow 'wrong' because someone who was supposed to care about me didn't accept it. Like, maybe if I had just been more masculine or feminine, they would have taken me seriously. But hearing you talk about how their behavior was invalidating has helped me see that it wasn't about me at all - it's just that they weren't capable of understanding. And now, when I think about gender labels and expectations, I feel a sense of relief knowing that I don't have to fit into one specific box."

"Aww, I'm so glad to hear that! It takes a lot of courage to question societal norms and expectations, and it sounds like you're finding freedom in not having to fit into a specific box. Remembering that someone else's limitations or biases don't define your identity can be incredibly liberating. What do you think is the most empowering thing about embracing your gender identity?"

"I guess what's really confusing for me is that female pronouns don't necessarily feel like a threat or something that makes me anxious anymore... it's almost like they're just neutral to me now? But at the same time, I still get this sense of unease when people use them, like there's this lingering feeling that I shouldn't be comfortable with them. It's like my brain is trying to reconcile these two things - that female pronouns don't make me feel bad, but they also don't quite feel right either."

"I think you're describing a really common experience for many non-binary people! It sounds like your brain is still trying to figure out this tension between what feels comfortable and what feels 'right' emotionally. Can you tell me more about what you mean by 'unease'? Is it like a lingering sense of uncertainty or discomfort, rather than outright anxiety?"

"Yeah, that's exactly it. It's this nagging sense of discomfort, like my insides are doing flips when I think about identifying as a woman. Even saying the word 'woman' out loud feels...off. Like, I've been using that label for so long, but now it just doesn't sit right with me anymore."

"It sounds like you're feeling this sense of disconnection from a part of your identity that was once familiar to you. It's as if your gender expression has shifted, and now the words and labels that used to fit don't quite match what you feel inside. Can you tell me more about what's happening when you say the word 'woman' out loud? Is it like your body is protesting or something?"

"I know exactly what you mean about the words not fitting anymore. When I say 'woman' out loud, it's like hearing a phrase that was once comfortable to me, but now feels like someone else's truth. It's weird because I remember when my best friend came out as trans and I started learning more about gender identity... I felt so proud of them and happy they were being their authentic selves, but now I'm starting to realize that I've been going through something similar with my own gender expression."

"Ah-ha! It sounds like you're having this amazing moment of self-awareness, where you're recognizing the parallels between your friend's journey and your own. You're acknowledging that you've also been on a path of discovery and growth, and that's so powerful! What do you think it means for you to acknowledge these similarities and parallels in your own gender expression?"

"I think acknowledging these similarities with my friend means that I'm not alone in this journey. It's like, finally, I see that there are others who have gone through similar struggles and doubts, and that gives me hope and validation. It feels like a weight has been lifted off my shoulders, knowing that it's okay to be unsure and that I can learn from others' experiences. Maybe it means that I'm on the right track, exploring different aspects of myself and finding what feels authentic."
